document.docAuthor: Terzani, Fabio, Ceccolini, Filippo, Hájek, Jiří & Cianferoni, Fabio
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic review of the genus Dascillus Latreille, 1797 in the Western Palaearctic (Coleoptera: Dascillidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic review of the genus Dascillus Latreille, 1797 in the Western Palaearctic (Coleoptera: Dascillidae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Ptinus testaceo-villosus
De Geer 1774 : 235
. Type locality: not specified. Synonymy by
Paykull (1799: 116)
.

Cistela ceruina ( Linnaeus, 1758 )
:
Fabricius (1781: 146)
. Type locality restricted to “Europa boreali [= northern Europe]”. Incorrect subsequent spelling for
Cistela cervina
.

Cistela cinerea
Fabricius 1781 : 146
. Type locality: “Italia [= Italy]”. Synonymy by
Paykull (1799: 117)
sub
Atopa cervina
var. β Paykull, 1799 .

Atopa elongata
Faldermann 1835 : 183
. Type locality: “Caucasus”. Syn. nov.

Dascillus sicanus
Fairmaire 1861 : 582
. Type locality: “Sicile, monts Madonies [= Sicily, Mts. Madonie]”. Syn. nov.

Dascillus parallelus
Dohrn 1872 : 482
. Type locality: “Vallombrosa, Toscana [= Italy, Tuscany, Vallombrosa]”. Previously synonymised by
Pic (1914: 14)
sub
D. sicanus
. Syn. nov.

Dascillus cervinus var. semiobscura
[sic!]
Pic 1908 : 41
. Type locality: “Volvic, mont Reculet, col de Forclaz, forêt de Turini, Grande Chartreuse, mont Pilat, Moldavie et Velebit [several localities in France, Switzerland, Croatia and Moldova]”. Synonymy by
Winkler (1926: 664)
.

Dascillus elongatus var. obscuricollis
Pic 1908b : 41
“Caucase et Tokat [Caucasus and Turkey, Tokat]”. Previously synonymised by
Winkler (1926: 664)
sub
D. elongatus
. Syn. nov.

Dascillus elongatus var. ruficollis
Pic 1908b : 41
. Type locality: “Caucase occidental [Western Caucasus]”. Previously synonymised by
Winkler (1926: 664)
sub
D. elongatus
. Syn. nov.

Dascillus aprutianus
Depoli 1936 : 137
, Type locality “Campo Imperatore [Italy, Abruzzo, Campo Imperatore]”. Included under synonyms of
D. sicanus
by
Jin et al. (2013 : 577
) with doubts; synonymy with
D. sicanus
formally established by
Hájek (2016: 19)
. Syn. nov.

Morphological observations. We have examined altogether 990
Dascillus
specimens from most regions of the Western Palaearctic. All characters previously used for alpha-taxonomy of Dascillidae were evaluated, especially: shape of elytra, length of antennomeres, length of legs, density and colouration of body setation, shape of abdominal sternite IX, and shape of male genitalia, see also
Jin et al. (2013)
. We have detected high variability in all mentioned characters both within and between populations, independent of geographic origin.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Habitus of
Dascillus cervinus
: a) Cavalese, Trentino-Alto Adige/Südtirol; b) Camaldoli, Tuscany; c) Madonie, Sicily; d) Moncerchio, Piedmont; e) Monti Sibillini, Marche; f) Sant’Agata di Esaro, Calabria. Scale bar = 2 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Colouration of integument and setation was one of the characters frequently used for identification of
Dascillus
taxa. For example, Fairmaire (1861) wrote that
Dascillus sicanus
differs from
D. cervinus
with ashreddish in colour of setation; Pic (1908) described several colour varieties for both
D. cervinus
and
D. elongatus
. Our study, however, documented a high individual variability of
Dascillus
body colouration, which is not constant within the particular populations (cf. Fig. 1 ).

Special attention was paid to the shape of the abdominal sternite IX.
Jin et al. (2013)
do not detect significant differences between
D. cervinus
and
D. sicanus
; however, they mentioned the differently shaped (posteriorly emarginated) sternite IX (incorrectly stated in the key by
Jin et al. 2013
: 561 as “tergite IX”) as a diagnostic character for the Caucasian
D. elongatus
. We have observed individual differences in the shape of sternite IX even within Italian populations, independent of their geographic origin ( Fig. 3 , particularly cf. a–e).

The shape of the aedeagus is a crucial character distinguishing
D. cervinus
from both
D. elongatus
and
D. sicanus
(see
Jin et al. 2013
). The differences purportedly regard the ventral lobe of the penis: flat and parallel sided in apical third in
D. cervinus
, while narrowing to apex in
D. elongatus
and
D. sicanus
. The apex of the dorsal lobe is indistinctly projecting medially in
D. cervinus
, contrary to the distinct medial projection in
D. elongatus
and
D. sicanus
. We detected a variability that is not constant and not specific for any population in both mentioned characters, showing that there are not significant differences to maintain a taxonomic separation of the three taxa. In addition, even the apex of the ventral lobe and the shape of parameres are highly variable ( Fig. 2 ), regardless of the origin of the populations (cf. Fig. 2 p,q).

As we were not able to observe any constant character suggesting the existence of several species, all individuals are considered to belong to
Dascillus cervinus
, with its new synonymies established below.

Comments on classification. We studied the type specimens of the Linnean
Chrysomela cervina
. The species was described from an unknown number of syntypes , three of which are preserved in the collection of the Linnean Society of London. To fix the unambiguous identity of the species, we have designated the lectotype , choosing the only specimen with an already everted aedeagus and thus not requiring dissection.

Pending future research, we have not investigated the 18th -century synonyms, namely
Ptinus testaceo-villosus
De Geer, 1774 and
Cistela cinerea Fabricius, 1781
. Without examining the original type material, it is not possible to verify these names as synonyms only from original descriptions and figures. We simply follow their synonymisation with
Dascillus cervinus
by Paykull (1799) .

Atopa elongata Faldermann, 1835
, was described from Caucasus. We were not able to study the type material of the species. It was found neither in the Zoological Museum of the Zoological Institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences (M. Volkovitsh, pers. comm.), nor in the Zoological Museum of Moscow State University (A. Ozerov and A. Gusakov, pers. comm.), nor at the Museum für Naturkunde Berlin (J. Frisch and B. Jaeger, pers. comm.). We have examined a number of specimens from the Caucasus area, previously identified as
Dascillus elongatus
(see Material examined), which agree well with the diagnosis of the species provided by
Jin et al. (2013)
, especially the projecting apex of the dorsal lobe of aedeagus, and abdominal sternite IX emarginate posteriorly. However, when compared with extensive material of
Dascillus
from other areas, all specimens are clearly referable to variability of
D. cervinus
(see Figs 2 and 3 ). Therefore, we consider
Dascillus elongatus ( Faldermann, 1835 )
as junior subjective synonym of
D. cervinus
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2. Aedeagus of
Dascillus cervinus
: a) Schweidnitz, Poland; b) Budapest, Hungary; c) Schöcke, Austria; d) Vodize, Croatia; e) Lizzola, Lombardy; f) Valbruna, Friuli-Venezia Giulia; g) Passo del Giogo, Tuscany; h) Campo Imperatore, Abruzzo; i) Campo Imperatore, Abruzzo; j) Serra Calvello, Basilicata; k) Vallombrosa, Tuscany, lectotypus of
D. parallelus
; l) Vallombrosa, Tuscany, paralectotypus of
D. parallelus
; m) Monti Orsomarso, Calabria; n) Monti Orsomarso, Calabria; o) Sicily; p) Agrigento, Sicily; q) Agrigento, Sicily; r) Bezinghi, “Caucasus”; s) Gebi Gesewzik, “Caucasus”; t) Arzakan, Armenia. Scale bar = 1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Fairmaire (1861) described
Dascillus sicanus
from Sicily (Italy) as very similar to
D. cervinus
, from which it differs in the following features: more parallel habitus; longer elytra; shorter legs; pronotum narrower in frontal part, with more sinuous sides and more obtuse posterior angles; shorter second antennomere (especially in the female); pubescence ash-reddish in colour, generally less abundant, forming narrow borders of denser pubescence along the posterior side of the pronotum, the suture, and lateral sides of the elytra; elytra more strongly bordered. The type material of
D. sicanus
should be in Fairmaire’s collection (MNHN). The material sent to us includes four specimens generically labelled “Sicile” or “Sicilia”, but without a topographical indication of the Madonie mountains (locus typicus of
D. sicanus
) and none of them with Fairmaire’s original identification label. Therefore, we do not consider them as syntypes and do not designate the lectotype.
Jin et al. (2013)
considered as a possible syntype a single specimen, generically labelled with “Sicile”, preserved at the Institute Royal des Sciences Naturelles de Belgique (Brussels, Belgium). However, even this material does not mention the type locality “mont Madonies” indicated by Fairmaire (1861) , so we do not think it is possible to consider even this specimen as a type with any certainty. However, we studied nine specimens (all males) from Sicily, including one from the type locality “Madonie”, comparing their external features with those used in the original description of
D. sicanus
. In particular, variability has been detected in the shape and length of the elytra, the length of the legs, the shape of the pronotum, the length of the second antennomere, and the density of pubescence and its colour. This variability falls completely within that of the other examined populations originating from throughout the species’ distribution range. Thus, concerning the habitus, no differences allowing a taxonomic separation at any level were detected ( Fig. 1 ). Indeed, Porta (1929) included in his dichotomous key some features of the pronotal shape, which are in contrast with the original description by Fairmaire (1861) .
Jin et al. (2013)
diagnosed
D. sicanus
based on the ventral lobe of the penis flattened with parallel sides in the apical third, and with the apex of the dorsal lobe distinctly projecting medially. In these characters, we detected a variability that is not constant and not specific for any population. Therefore, we consider
Dascillus sicanus Fairmaire, 1861
as a junior subjective synonym of
D. cervinus
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3. Sternite IX of
Dascillus cervinus
: a) Tarvisio, Friuli-Venezia Giulia; b) Tarvisio, Friuli-Venezia Giulia; c) Assergi, Abruzzo; d) L’Aquila, Abruzzo; e) Agrigento, Sicily; f) Mamison Pass, “Caucasus”. Scale bar = 1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Dascillus parallelus Dohrn, 1872
from Tuscany (Italy), was synonymised with
D. sicanus
by Pic (1914) . The species was described based on five specimens, four of which are preserved in the MSNG. We designate the lectotype to fix the unambiguous identity of the species. We did not find differences between
D. parallelus
and
D. cervinus
, neither in the habitus ( Fig. 4 ), nor in the aedeagus ( Fig. 2 -l). Therefore we formally establish
Dascillus parallelus Dohrn, 1872
as a junior subjective synonym of
D. cervinus
, in accordance with the fact that
D. parallelus
was previously treated as synonym of
D. sicanus
, a species concurrently synonymised with
D. cervinus
(see above).

Pic (1908) described three colour varieties,
Dascillus cervinus var. semiobscura
,
D. elongatus var. obscuricollis
and
D. elongatus var. ruficollis
. All of them were subsequently treated as infrasubspecific entities (see, e.g., Jakobson 1913 ; Winkler 1926 ) and synonymised with
D. cervinus
and
D. elongatus
, respectively (cf. Löbl 2006 ). We did not study those varieties, but simply establish the formal synonymy of the latter two with
D. cervinus
, following the synonymy of
D. elongatus
stated above.

Finally,
Dascillus aprutianus Depoli, 1936
was described based on a series from “Campo Imperatore” in the Gran Sasso mountains, Abruzzo (Italy). We searched for the type series deposited in Depoli’s collection stored in the Prirodoslovni muzej Rijeka (Croatia). The current curator (M. Kirinčić, pers. comm.) found indications that the type series had been lent in the past to an unknown addressee, and were never returned. Thus, the types are not detectable and we had to refer to topotypic material. We have examined 73 males and 52 females from the type locality and paid special attention to study features of the aedeagus ( Fig. 2 h,i)—the diagnostic character mentioned already by Binaghi (1955) . However, we found no distinctive differences in the shape of aedaegus between
D. aprutianus
and
D. cervinus
, and believe that the observations of Binaghi (1955) are related to the aedeagal variability of
D. cervinus
. Therefore, we consider
Dascillus aprutianus Depoli, 1936
as junior subjective synonym of
D. cervinus
, in accordance also with the the synonymisation of the species with
D. sicanus
(
Jin et al. 2013
; Hájek 2016 ), a species here synonymised with
D. cervinus
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4. Habitus and labels of the types of
Dascillus parallelus
: a) Lectotypus; b) Paralectotypus, female. Scale bar = 2 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution.
Dascillus cervinus
occurs in the whole territory of Europe, from Portugal and Ireland to the Ural mountains in Russia and Caucasus. The distribution in Romania is missing in the Palaearctic catalogue ( Hájek 2016 ); however, it was published from there, e.g., by Merkl (2008) . We provide the first country records from Albania , Bosnia and Herzegovina , Montenegro and
Macedonia
.

In Asia,
D. cervinus
is known from Turkey, Armenia and Iran. The record presented here from Syria remains doubtful, as the precise locality is missing and “Syria” in the 19th century also included present-day southern Turkey.
